elements.content: A microporous oxalamide-functionalized NbO-type metal–organic framework, HNUST-3, has been designed and synthesized by self-assembling [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheel SBUs and a novel tetracarboxylate ligand with linking oxalamide groups. HNUST-3 represents the first example of a porous oxalamide-functionalized MOF, which exhibits a high BET surface area of 2412 m2·g–1, large H2 uptake (unsaturated total capacity of 6.1 wt % at 20 bar and 77 K), and excellent CH4 storage (135.8 cm3(STP)cm–3 at 20 bar and 298 K) as well as high CO2 adsorption capacity (20.2 mmol·g–1 at 20 bar and 298 K) with good selectivity for CO2 over CH4 (7.9) and N2 (26.1) at 298 K.
elements.clean_text: A microporous oxalamide-functionalized NbO-type metal-organic framework, HNUST-3, has been designed and synthesized by self-assembling [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheel SBUs and a novel tetracarboxylate ligand with linking oxalamide groups. HNUST-3 represents the first example of a porous oxalamide-functionalized MOF, which exhibits a high BET surface area of 2412 m2⋅g-1, large H2 uptake (unsaturated total capacity of 6.1 wt % at 20 bar and 77 K), and excellent CH4 storage (135.8 cm3(STP)cm-3 at 20 bar and 298 K) as well as high CO2 adsorption capacity (20.2 mmol⋅g-1 at 20 bar and 298 K) with good selectivity for CO2 over CH4 (7.9) and N2 (26.1) at 298 K.

elements.content: A microporous oxalamide-functionalized NbO-type metal−organic framework with high surface area, HNUST-3, has been successfully designed from a novel oxalamide-bridging tetracarboxylate ligand and Cu(II) paddlewheel SBUs, exhibiting large multigas-uptake capacity.
elements.clean_text: A microporous oxalamide-functionalized NbO-type metal-organic framework with high surface area, HNUST-3, has been successfully designed from a novel oxalamide-bridging tetracarboxylate ligand and Cu(II) paddlewheel SBUs, exhibiting large multigas-uptake capacity.

elements.content: Emerging as a novel class of crystalline porous materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are of great promise for their potential use in the strategic storage and separation of hydrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide in clean-energy applications. Compared with traditional porous materials (zeolite, active carbon, etc.), MOFs not only exhibit a large gas-uptake capacity but also structures that can be carefully designed toward higher performance. It has been well-documented that besides the large surface area and pore volume, a high gas affinity of materials involving strong host–guest interactions is also essential to realize high gas-uptake capacity. Thus, several strategies have been introduced to improve framework–gas interactions: (i) decorating MOFs with some specific functional groups (−NH2, −NO2, −OH, etc.) that have high binding affinity to gas molecules by postsynthetic modification or directly using functionalized organic linkers, (ii) narrowing the pore size by interpenetration, and (iii) shortening the size of the ligands in MOFs with isoreticular structures. Indeed, these strategies can significantly increase the gas-binding affinity; however, they also generally lead to a decline in gas-uptake capacity because of the decreased surface area and pore volume.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Emerging as a novel class of crystalline porous materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are of great promise for their potential use in the strategic storage and separation of hydrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide in clean-energy applications. Compared with traditional porous materials (zeolite, active carbon, etc.), MOFs not only exhibit a large gas-uptake capacity but also structures that can be carefully designed toward higher performance. It has been well-documented that besides the large surface area and pore volume, a high gas affinity of materials involving strong host-guest interactions is also essential to realize high gas-uptake capacity. Thus, several strategies have been introduced to improve framework-gas interactions: (i) decorating MOFs with some specific functional groups (-NH2, -NO2, -OH, etc.) that have high binding affinity to gas molecules by postsynthetic modification or directly using functionalized organic linkers, (ii) narrowing the pore size by interpenetration, and (iii) shortening the size of the ligands in MOFs with isoreticular structures. Indeed, these strategies can significantly increase the gas-binding affinity; however, they also generally lead to a decline in gas-uptake capacity because of the decreased surface area and pore volume.

elements.content: We are interested in the construction of porous functionalized MOF materials from large multidentate carboxylate ligands with linking functionalities (−CONH–, −CC–, etc.) because such an approach may facilitate the generation of expanded frameworks with high surface area and, most importantly, the gas sorption capacity of MOFs may be dramatically enhanced by strong interactions between target gas molecules and the functional groups predesigned in the frameworks. By working with this consideration, very recently we successfully inserted linking acylamide functional groups into several MOFs and realized a balance between high gas-binding ability and large gas-storage capacity. To expand our work in this area, we herein report an oxalamide-functionalized microporous NbO-type MOF, termed HNUST-3 (HNUST denotes Hunan University of Science and Technology), designed from a tetracarboxylate ligand with bridging oxalamide moiety (N,N′-bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)oxalamide = H4BDPO, Scheme ). To the best of our knowledge, HNUST-3 represents the first example of a porous oxalamide-functionalized MOF. HNUST-3 exhibits a high Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 2412 m2·g–1 and a large unsaturated total hydrogen-storage capacity of 6.1 wt % at 77 K and 20 bar. Additionally, this MOF material also demonstrates excellent CH4 storage of 135.8 cm3(STP)cm–3 at 20 bar and 298 K and high CO2 uptake capacity of 20.2 mmol·g–1 at 20 bar and 298 K as well as good selectivity of CO2/N2 (26.1) and CO2/CH4 (7.9).

elements.content: All chemical reagents were obtained from commercial sources and, unless otherwise noted, were used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out on a PerkinElmer 240 analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained on a VECTOR TM 22 spectrometer with KBr pellets in the 4000–400 cm–1 region. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX-500 spectrometer with tetramethylsilane as an internal reference. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under a N2 atmosphere (100 mL/min) with a heating rate of 5 °C/min using a 2960 SDT thermogravimetric analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at room temperature with a routine power of 1600 W (40 kV, 40 mA) at a scan speed of 5°/min and a step size of 0.02 in 2θ. The simulated PXRD spectra were acquired by the diffraction-crystal module of the Mercury program based on the single-crystal data. The program is available free of charge via the Internet at http://www.iucr.org.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Material and Measurements

All chemical reagents were obtained from commercial sources and, unless otherwise noted, were used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were carried out on a PerkinElmer 240 analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained on a VECTOR TM 22 spectrometer with KBr pellets in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX-500 spectrometer with tetramethylsilane as an internal reference. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under a N2 atmosphere (100 mL/min) with a heating rate of 5 °C/min using a 2960 SDT thermogravimetric analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at room temperature with a routine power of 1600 W (40 kV, 40 mA) at a scan speed of 5°/min and a step size of 0.02 in 2θ. The simulated PXRD spectra were acquired by the diffraction-crystal module of the Mercury program based on the single-crystal data. The program is available free of charge via the Internet at http://www.iucr.org.

elements.content: 5-Aminoisophthalic acid (2.70 g, 95%, 15.0 mmol) was dissolved in 40 mL of anhydrous N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone. While under nitrogen flow at 0 °C, oxalyl chloride (0.668 g, 5.26 mmol) was added all at once. After stirring for 30 min at 0 °C and 12 h at room temperature, the reaction mixture was poured into a large excess of water. The precipitated solids were filtered off and washed repeatedly with hot methanol and then dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C to obtain about 0.9 g (yield: ∼41%) of clean H4BDPO as a white powder. Anal. Calcd for C18H12N2O10: C, 51.93; H, 2.91; N, 6.73. Found: C, 51.89; H, 3.14; N, 6.79. Selected IR (KBr, cm–1): 3102, 1713, 1608, 1541, 1457, 1393, 1301, 1227, 1172, 910, 791, 761, 669. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, δ ppm): 13.331 (broad peak, COOH), 11.269 (s, 2H, CONH), 8.725 (d, 4H, ArH), 8.272 (s, 2H, ArH).

Synthesis of the Ligand N,N'-Bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)oxalamide, H4BDPO

5-Aminoisophthalic acid (2.70 g, 95%, 15.0 mmol) was dissolved in 40 mL of anhydrous N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone. While under nitrogen flow at 0 °C, oxalyl chloride (0.668 g, 5.26 mmol) was added all at once. After stirring for 30 min at 0 °C and 12 h at room temperature, the reaction mixture was poured into a large excess of water. The precipitated solids were filtered off and washed repeatedly with hot methanol and then dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C to obtain about 0.9 g (yield: ~41%) of clean H4BDPO as a white powder. Anal. Calcd for C18H12N2O10: C, 51.93; H, 2.91; N, 6.73. Found: C, 51.89; H, 3.14; N, 6.79. Selected IR (KBr, cm-1): 3102, 1713, 1608, 1541, 1457, 1393, 1301, 1227, 1172, 910, 791, 761, 669. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, δ ppm): 13.331 (broad peak, COOH), 11.269 (s, 2H, CONH), 8.725 (d, 4H, ArH), 8.272 (s, 2H, ArH).

elements.content: H4BDPO (10.4 mg, 0.025 mmol), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (25 mg, 0.1 mmol), DMF (2 mL), ethanol (1.6 mL), H2O (1.6 mL), and concentrated HNO3 (400 μL) were mixed and stirred for a few minutes in air and then the clear solution was transferred into a autoclave Teflon-line stainless vessel (20 mL). The vessel was sealed and heated at 75 °C for 2 days and then cooled to room temperature. Pale-blue block crystals of HNUST-3 were obtained and then washed by DMF to yield about 10.0 mg (yield: ∼70% based on the ligand). The crystals of HNUST-3 are stable for common organic solvents except for water, and it becomes opaque after exposure for several minutes in air. Satisfactory elemental analysis data could not be obtained, despite several attempts. This could be attributed to the fact that the extent of the solvent molecules in the cavity may vary from the exposure time of the sample to air. Selected IR (KBr, cm–1): 1654, 1586, 1374, 1413, 1253, 1174, 1105, 776, 730.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of HNUST-3

H4BDPO (10.4 mg, 0.025 mmol), Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (25 mg, 0.1 mmol), DMF (2 mL), ethanol (1.6 mL), H2O (1.6 mL), and concentrated HNO3 (400 μL) were mixed and stirred for a few minutes in air and then the clear solution was transferred into a autoclave Teflon-line stainless vessel (20 mL). The vessel was sealed and heated at 75 °C for 2 days and then cooled to room temperature. Pale-blue block crystals of HNUST-3 were obtained and then washed by DMF to yield about 10.0 mg (yield: ~70% based on the ligand). The crystals of HNUST-3 are stable for common organic solvents except for water, and it becomes opaque after exposure for several minutes in air. Satisfactory elemental analysis data could not be obtained, despite several attempts. This could be attributed to the fact that the extent of the solvent molecules in the cavity may vary from the exposure time of the sample to air. Selected IR (KBr, cm-1): 1654, 1586, 1374, 1413, 1253, 1174, 1105, 776, 730.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction was performed with a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer with a graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using the ω-scan technique at 298 K. The CCD data were integrated and scaled using the Bruker-SAINT software package. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix leas-squares techniques based on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and H atoms were placed in calculated positions with isotropic displacement parameters set to 1.2 × U eq of the attached atom. Disordered, independent solvent molecules inside the frameworks were eliminated in the refinement by PLATON/SQUEEZE. Structural information of HNUST-3 was deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC reference number ). Crystallographic data for HNUST-3: C54H24Cu6N6O35.56, fw = 1707.07, monoclinic, P21/c, a = 28.180(2) Å, b = 18.4040(14) Å, c = 32.044(2) Å, α = γ = 90°, β = 112.1740(10)°, V = 15389.7(19) Å3, Z = 4, T = 293(2) K, μ = 0.857 mm–1, 116 696 reflections were collected (28 132 were unique) for 1.30° < θ < 25.35°, R(int) = 0.0691, R 1 = 0.0675, wR 2 = 0.1840 [I > 2σ(I)], R 1 = 0.0921, wR 2 = 0.1963 (all data), GOF = 1.001.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Structure Determination

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction was performed with a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer with a graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using the ω-scan technique at 298 K. The CCD data were integrated and scaled using the Bruker-SAINT software package. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix leas-squares techniques based on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and H atoms were placed in calculated positions with isotropic displacement parameters set to 1.2 × U eq of the attached atom. Disordered, independent solvent molecules inside the frameworks were eliminated in the refinement by PLATON/SQUEEZE. Structural information of HNUST-3 was deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC reference number ). Crystallographic data for HNUST-3: C54H24Cu6N6O35.56, fw = 1707.07, monoclinic, P21/c, a = 28.180(2) Å, b = 18.4040(14) Å, c = 32.044(2) Å, α = γ = 90°, β = 112.1740(10)°, V = 15389.7(19) Å3, Z = 4, T = 293(2) K, μ = 0.857 mm-1, 116696 reflections were collected (28132 were unique) for 1.30° < θ < 25.35°, R(int) = 0.0691, R 1 = 0.0675, wR 2 = 0.1840 [I > 2σ(I)], R 1 = 0.0921, wR 2 = 0.1963 (all data), GOF = 1.001.

elements.content: As-synthesized HNUST-3 crystals were immersed in anhydrous acetone for 3 days to remove the nonvolatile solvates (DMF and water), the extract was decanted every 8 h, and fresh anhydrous acetone was replaced. After the removal of acetone by decanting, the sample was further activated by drying under a dynamic high vacuum at 100 °C overnight to obtain the desolvated sample. During this time, a color change from pale-blue (in DMF) to blue (in acetone) to deep purple-blue (activated) was observed, typical for Cu(II)-paddlewheel frameworks in which open copper sites were generated. The desolvated sample was moisture-sensitive, and a few minutes of exposure to air could change the sample’s color back to pale green. Anal. Calcd for activated HNUST-3 (C9H4NCuO5, fw = 369.68 g mol–1): C, 40.08; H, 1.50; N, 5.19. Found: C, 40.15; H, 1.65; N, 5.26. Selected IR (KBr, cm–1): 1617, 1561, 1401, 1176, 775, 723, 532.
elements.clean_text:
Sample Activation

As-synthesized HNUST-3 crystals were immersed in anhydrous acetone for 3 days to remove the nonvolatile solvates (DMF and water), the extract was decanted every 8 h, and fresh anhydrous acetone was replaced. After the removal of acetone by decanting, the sample was further activated by drying under a dynamic high vacuum at 100 °C overnight to obtain the desolvated sample. During this time, a color change from pale-blue (in DMF) to blue (in acetone) to deep purple-blue (activated) was observed, typical for Cu(II)-paddlewheel frameworks in which open copper sites were generated. The desolvated sample was moisture-sensitive, and a few minutes of exposure to air could change the sample's color back to pale green. Anal. Calcd for activated HNUST-3 (C9H4NCuO5, fw = 369.68 g mol-1): C, 40.08; H, 1.50; N, 5.19. Found: C, 40.15; H, 1.65; N, 5.26. Selected IR (KBr, cm-1): 1617, 1561, 1401, 1176, 775, 723, 532.

elements.content: In the gas sorption measurements, all of the gas used are of 99.999% purity. Low-pressure (up to 1 bar) nitrogen (N2, at 77 K; Ar, at 87 K), hydrogen (H2, at 77 and 87 K), carbon dioxide (CO2, at 273 and 298 K), methane (CH4, at 273 and 298 K), and N2 (at 273 and 298 K) sorption experiments were carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 M+C surface area analyzer. For all low-pressure isotherms, warm and cold free-space correction measurements were performed using ultra-high-purity He gas (UHP grade 5.0, 99.999% purity). A part of the N2 sorption isotherm at 77 K in the P/P 0 range 0.0003–0.003 was fitted to the BET equation to estimate the BET surface area, and the Langmuir surface area calculation was performed using all data points (). The pore-size distribution (PSD) was obtained from the DFT model in the Micromeritics ASAP2020 software package (assuming split pore geometry) based on the N2 sorption isotherm. High-pressure adsorption isotherms of H2 (at 77 K), CO2 (at 273 and 298 K), CH4 (at 273 and 298 K), and N2 (at 273 and 298 K) were measured using an IGA-003 gravimetric adsorption instrument (Hiden-Isochema) over a pressure range of 0–20 bar. For high-pressure measurements, the completely activated sample mass was monitored until equilibrium was reached (within 25 min) at each pressure. The total high-pressure gas uptake was calculated by N total = N excess + ρbulk V pore, where ρbulk is the density of compressed gas at the measured temperature and V pore is the pore volume of the sample that was obtained from the N2 isotherm at 77 K.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption Experiments

In the gas sorption measurements, all of the gas used are of 99.999% purity. Low-pressure (up to 1 bar) nitrogen (N2, at 77 K; Ar, at 87 K), hydrogen (H2, at 77 and 87 K), carbon dioxide (CO2, at 273 and 298 K), methane (CH4, at 273 and 298 K), and N2 (at 273 and 298 K) sorption experiments were carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 M+C surface area analyzer. For all low-pressure isotherms, warm and cold free-space correction measurements were performed using ultra-high-purity He gas (UHP grade 5.0, 99.999% purity). A part of the N2 sorption isotherm at 77 K in the P/P 0 range 0.0003-0.003 was fitted to the BET equation to estimate the BET surface area, and the Langmuir surface area calculation was performed using all data points (). The pore-size distribution (PSD) was obtained from the DFT model in the Micromeritics ASAP2020 software package (assuming split pore geometry) based on the N2 sorption isotherm. High-pressure adsorption isotherms of H2 (at 77 K), CO2 (at 273 and 298 K), CH4 (at 273 and 298 K), and N2 (at 273 and 298 K) were measured using an IGA-003 gravimetric adsorption instrument (Hiden-Isochema) over a pressure range of 0-20 bar. For high-pressure measurements, the completely activated sample mass was monitored until equilibrium was reached (within 25 min) at each pressure. The total high-pressure gas uptake was calculated by N total = N excess + ρbulk V pore, where ρbulk is the density of compressed gas at the measured temperature and V pore is the pore volume of the sample that was obtained from the N2 isotherm at 77 K.

elements.content: Solvothermal reaction of H4BDPO and Cu(NO3)·2.5H2O in DMF/ethanol/H2O (5: 4: 4 v/v/v) under acidic (HNO3) conditions at 75 °C affords block-shaped pale-blue single crystals of [Cu2BDPO(H2O)4] (HNUST-3) in about 70% yield (based on the ligand). A single-crystal structure determination revealed that HNUST-3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c, distinct from the prototype framework PCN-46 that adopts the trigonal space group R3̅m. The 3D framework of HNUST-3 is built of four connected square [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheels bridged through four branched BDPO linkers (Figure ), with each Cu(II) center coordinated to one water molecule along the axis of the paddlewheel. Each ligand links to four different [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheels and forms a four-connected node. The oxalamide group of ligand BDPO is metal-free in HNUST-3 and only acts as extending moieties of the framework. Thus, HNUST-3 has a noninterpenetrated 4,4-connected framework structure of an augmented NbO topology, the same as other reported MOFs assembled from tetratopic linkers and paddlewheels SBUs. To the best of our knowledge, HNUST-3 reperesents the first example of porous oxalamide-functionalized MOF. In HNUST-3, two different types of cages are also present (Figure ): a smaller ellipsoidal cage of approximately 1.2 nm in diameter and a larger spherical cage with a diameter of approximately 1.3 nm (after considering the van der Waals radii of the atoms). These two types of cages are connected to each other by sharing three paddlewheel SBUs between two adjacent ones of different types, resulting in a highly porous 3D framework (Figure c). The void volume in the desolvated HNUST-3 calculated from PLATON/SOLV reaches up to 73.2% with a low calculated density of 0.686 g·cm–3.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure and Framework Stability

Solvothermal reaction of H4BDPO and Cu(NO3)⋅2.5H2O in DMF/ethanol/H2O (5: 4: 4 v/v/v) under acidic (HNO3) conditions at 75 °C affords block-shaped pale-blue single crystals of [Cu2BDPO(H2O)4] (HNUST-3) in about 70% yield (based on the ligand). A single-crystal structure determination revealed that HNUST-3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c, distinct from the prototype framework PCN-46 that adopts the trigonal space group R3̅m. The 3D framework of HNUST-3 is built of four connected square [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheels bridged through four branched BDPO linkers (Figure ), with each Cu(II) center coordinated to one water molecule along the axis of the paddlewheel. Each ligand links to four different [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheels and forms a four-connected node. The oxalamide group of ligand BDPO is metal-free in HNUST-3 and only acts as extending moieties of the framework. Thus, HNUST-3 has a noninterpenetrated 4,4-connected framework structure of an augmented NbO topology, the same as other reported MOFs assembled from tetratopic linkers and paddlewheels SBUs. To the best of our knowledge, HNUST-3 reperesents the first example of porous oxalamide-functionalized MOF. In HNUST-3, two different types of cages are also present (Figure ): a smaller ellipsoidal cage of approximately 1.2 nm in diameter and a larger spherical cage with a diameter of approximately 1.3 nm (after considering the van der Waals radii of the atoms). These two types of cages are connected to each other by sharing three paddlewheel SBUs between two adjacent ones of different types, resulting in a highly porous 3D framework (Figure c). The void volume in the desolvated HNUST-3 calculated from PLATON/SOLV reaches up to 73.2% with a low calculated density of 0.686 g⋅cm-3.

elements.content: The framework stability of HNUST-3 was studied by both thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements. TGA of the fresh HNUST-3 sample revealed that HNUST-3 loses guest DMF solvent molecules trapped in the cages and coordinated water molecules from 30 to ∼200 °C, and a further significant weight loss is observed up to 300 °C (). To obtain the fully desolvated framework, the fresh HNUST-3 sample was repeatedly soaked in anhydrous acetone for 3 days to exchange the less volatile DMF solvent followed by heating under a dynamic vacuum at 100 °C overnight. A color change from pale-blue to purple-blue occurred, indicating that open Cu(II) sites have been generated similar to those observed for other frameworks. The PXRD patterns of desolvated HNUST-3 are completely identical to those for both as-synthesized and simulated from single-crystal data (Figure ), indicating that the framework is robust and retains its crystallinity after activation.

elements.content: To evaluate the permanent porosity of HNUST-3, N2 (77 K) and Ar (87 K) gas adsorption studies were performed on the activated sample. As shown in Figure , both isotherms exhibit typical type-I adsorption behavior, as expected for microporous materials. On the basis of the N2 adsorption isotherm, the surface area of activated HNUST-3 calculated from the Langmuir equation is about 2784 m2·g–1, and the corresponding BET surface area is 2412 m2·g–1. This BET value is smaller than that reported for isoreticular analoge NJU-Bai12 (3038 m2·g–1), NOTT-102 (2942 m2·g–1), and NOTT-103 (2929 m2·g–1), but it is significantly larger than that of NOTT-109 (1718 m2·g–1) and PCN-14 (1753 m2·g–1) and is fairly comparable to the values of other highly porous NbO-type MOFs such as SNU-50 (2300 m2·g–1), NOTT-101 (2316 m2·g–1), HNUST-2 (2366 m2·g–1), NOTT-105 (2387 m2·g–1), and PCN-46 (2500 m2·g–1), thus making HNUST-3 among the highest surface area NbO-type MOF series reported to date. The inset to Figure shows the differential pore volume distributions as functions of pore width calculated by nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) from N2 isotherm data, which suggests that HNUST-3 has a narrow pore-size distributions around 1.0–1.2 nm, corresponding with the crystal model. The total pore volume of HNUST-3 calculated from the maximum amount of N2 adsorbed at 77 K reaches up to 0.99 cm3·g–1, consistent with the total framework pore volume (1.07 cm3·g–1) derived from the X-ray crystal structure of HNUST-3.

As shown in Figure , both isotherms exhibit typical type-I adsorption behavior, as expected for microporous materials. On the basis of the N2 adsorption isotherm, the surface area of activated HNUST-3 calculated from the Langmuir equation is about 2784 m2⋅g-1, and the corresponding BET surface area is 2412 m2⋅g-1. This BET value is smaller than that reported for isoreticular analoge NJU-Bai12 (3038 m2⋅g-1), NOTT-102 (2942 m2⋅g-1), and NOTT-103 (2929 m2⋅g-1), but it is significantly larger than that of NOTT-109 (1718 m2⋅g-1) and PCN-14 (1753 m2⋅g-1) and is fairly comparable to the values of other highly porous NbO-type MOFs such as SNU-50 (2300 m2⋅g-1), NOTT-101 (2316 m2⋅g-1), HNUST-2 (2366 m2⋅g-1), NOTT-105 (2387 m2⋅g-1), and PCN-46 (2500 m2⋅g-1), thus making HNUST-3 among the highest surface area NbO-type MOF series reported to date. The inset to Figure  shows the differential pore volume distributions as functions of pore width calculated by nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) from N2 isotherm data, which suggests that HNUST-3 has a narrow pore-size distributions around 1.0-1.2 nm, corresponding with the crystal model. The total pore volume of HNUST-3 calculated from the maximum amount of N2 adsorbed at 77 K reaches up to 0.99 cm3⋅g-1, consistent with the total framework pore volume (1.07 cm3⋅g-1) derived from the X-ray crystal structure of HNUST-3.

elements.content: Because of its high power density of 33.3 kW h kg–1 (higher than methane at 13.9 kW h kg–1 and gasoline at 12.4 kW h kg–1), abundance, and nonpolluting nature, hydrogen is considered to be an ideal energy source candidate in the future. However, the lack of an effective storage method hinders the realization of the hydrogen economy era. During the past 2 decades, porous MOFs have been highlighted as promising candidates for use as a hydrogen storage material by virtue of their high porosity, tunable pore size, and large internal surface area. The high porosity and stable framework with open copper(II) sites suggest HNUST-3 may have an excellent H2 storage property. Indeed, HNUST-3 exhibits a high total H2-uptake capacity of 2.2 wt % [wt % = 100(mass of adsorbed gas)/(mass of MOF)] at 77 K and 1 bar (), which is larger than the corresponding value of PCN-46 (1.9 wt %) and is among the highest H2 uptakes at low pressure. High-pressure gravimetric H2 adsorption data were also recorded over the pressure range 0–20 bar at 77 K (Figure ), and HNUST-3 gives a maximum excess H2 uptake of 5.4 wt % (37.0 g·L–1) at 20 bar with no hysteresis. Taking into consideration the gaseous hydrogen compressed within the framework void, the total H2 uptake capacity of HNUST-3 can reach as high as 6.1 wt % (41.8 g·L–1) at 20 bar and 77 K, which is moderate compared with the highest capacity MOF materials. On the basis of the adsorption isotherms measured at 77 and 87 K, the zero-coverage H2 adsorption enthalpy of HNUST-3 is calculated to be 6.38 kJ·mol–1 with the virial method, which is quite large compared to other Cu(II)-based metal polyhedral frameworks with average adsorption enthalpies of 5.6–6.2 kJ·mol–1.

Gas Storage Properties

However, the lack of an effective storage method hinders the realization of the hydrogen economy era. The high porosity and stable framework with open copper(II) sites suggest HNUST-3 may have an excellent H2 storage property. Indeed, HNUST-3 exhibits a high total H2-uptake capacity of 2.2 wt % [wt % = 100(mass of adsorbed gas)/(mass of MOF)] at 77 K and 1 bar (), which is larger than the corresponding value of PCN-46 (1.9 wt %) and is among the highest H2 uptakes at low pressure. On the basis of the adsorption isotherms measured at 77 and 87 K, the zero-coverage H2 adsorption enthalpy of HNUST-3 is calculated to be 6.38 kJ⋅mol-1 with the virial method, which is quite large compared to other Cu(II)-based metal polyhedral frameworks with average adsorption enthalpies of 5.6-6.2 kJ⋅mol-1.

elements.content: Carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) has been proposed as a feasible method for controlling atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration. MOF-based porous materials exhibit great potential in CCS because they can store greater amounts of CO2 than other classes of porous materials and their chemically adjustable organic and inorganic moieties can be carefully predesigned to be suitable for molecular recognition of CO2. Our recent work clearly demonstrates that insertion of acylamide groups into porous MOFs can significantly increase the CO2-uptake capacity and selectivity of the materials because of the enhanced CO2-binding affinity. The BDPO ligand features similar linking oxalamide groups, and this prompted us to investigate the CO2-uptake performance of HNUST-3. Interestingly, HNUST-3 can adsorb substantial amounts of CO2 with uptake capacities of 33.15 wt % at 273 K and 16.6 wt % at 298 K under 1 atm of pressure (). These values are quite larger than that of the best performing ZIF material (ZIF-20, 13.7 wt % at 273 K and 1 atm), PCN-46 (ca. 13.2 wt % at 298 K and 1 atm), SUN-50 (21 wt % at 273 K and 1 atm), and most of other highly porous MOFs under the same conditions. Notably, as shown in Figure , the CO2 uptake amounts of HNUST-3 at 273 and 298 K are not saturated at 20 bar, with the values of 98.9 and 89.0 wt % (about 22.47 and 20.23 mmol·g–1), respectively. This CO2-uptake capacity is greater than those of some typical high-surface-area MOFs reported, such as MOF-210 (16.0 mmol·g–1), MOF-200 (14.8 mmol·g–1), and MOF-5 (19.0 mmol·g–1) at 20 bar and 298 K. In addition, on the basis of the total capacity, a container filled with HNUST-3 can store about 16 times the amount of CO2 in an empty container at 20 bar and 298 K, further indicating that HNUST-3 is a good and efficient CO2 adsorbent.

elements.content: Methane gas is another alternative on-board fuel that has attracted much interest. Compared with H2 storage, MOFs offer much more promise for use in CH4 storage because higher CH4 adsorption performance can be achieved. Up until now, several MOF compounds have been reported to exhibit exceptional CH4 uptake that surpasses the DOE standard (180 cm3·cm–3) at room temperature and 35 bar. Notably, a MOF methane fuel tank has already been implemented in test vehicles. To investigate the CH4 gas-storage capacity of HNUST-3, a gravimetric CH4 adsorption isotherm was recorded up to 20 bar at both 273 and 298 K. As shown in Figure , the CH4 isotherm also shows typical type-I behavior with good reversibility and fast kinetics. Most importantly, HNUST-3 possesses a completely reversible high CH4 adsorption at near ambient temperature. A large unsaturation excess CH4 uptake of 18.75 and 14.14 wt % (∼ 11.7 and 8.8 mmol·g–1) is observed at 273 and 298 K under 20 bar, respectively, corresponding to volumetric (v/v) uptakes of 180.1 and 135.8 cm3(STP)cm–3. This CH4 uptake capacity is lower than the DOE standard, but it is comparable to other MOF materials under higher pressures at 298 K (Mg-MOF-74, 149 cm3(STP)cm–3 at 35 bar; IRMOF-1, 135 cm3(STP)cm–3 at 35 bar; and MIL-101c, 100 cm3(STP)cm–3 at 35 bar).

elements.content: To monitor further the general gas sorption capacity and selectivity of HNUST-3, high-pressure gravimetric N2 sorption measurements have also been carried out at 298 and 273 K in the pressure range of 0–20 bar. In sharp contrast to CO2 and CH4, HNUST-3 can only absorb limited amounts of N2 (15.6 and 11.3 wt % at 273 and 298 K, respectively) at 20 bar (Figure ). The discrepancies among gas adsorption behavior indicate the different affinities with the framework, and the zero-coverage adsorption enthalpies of CO2, CH4, and N2 were calculated by the viral method to be 24.8, 15.4, and 11.8 kJ·mol–1 (), respectively. Compared with CH4 and N2, the strong interaction of CO2 with the framework can be largely attributed to the large quadrupole moment of CO2 compared to CH4 and N2 as well as to the presence of coordinatively unsaturated metal sites and polar oxalamide groups in HNUST-3, which are both preferred by CO2 molecules, thus leading to the selectivity of CO2 toward CH4 and N2. The CO2/CH4 and CO2/N2 selectivity calculated from the initial slopes of the isotherms reaches up to 7.9 and 26.1 at 298 K, respectively (); these values are much higher than the corresponding data of MOF-177 (4.4 and 17.5) and most other MOF materials (mainly in the range of 3–10 and 10–50, respectively), indicating that the introduction of oxalamide groups into MOFs may enhance the selectivity.

elements.content: A highly porous and robust MOF (HNUST-3) with a (4,4)-connected network topology has been synthesized by using a unique tetracarboxylate ligand bearing polar oxalamide groups. HNUST-3 represents the first example of a porous oxalamide-functionalized MOF and exhibits high multigas (H2, CO2, and CH4) uptake capacity with good adsorption selectivity of CO2 over CH4 and N2. This work demonstrates that inserting polar oxalamide groups into frameworks provides a promising route for fine-tuning MOF structures, which not only may effectively boost and/or maintain the MOF materials’ surface area and pore volume but also significantly improve gas-binding abilities (especially for CO2), thereby enhancing gas uptake and selectivity. Work along this strategy is currently underway in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A highly porous and robust MOF (HNUST-3) with a (4,4)-connected network topology has been synthesized by using a unique tetracarboxylate ligand bearing polar oxalamide groups. HNUST-3 represents the first example of a porous oxalamide-functionalized MOF and exhibits high multigas (H2, CO2, and CH4) uptake capacity with good adsorption selectivity of CO2 over CH4 and N2. This work demonstrates that inserting polar oxalamide groups into frameworks provides a promising route for fine-tuning MOF structures, which not only may effectively boost and/or maintain the MOF materials' surface area and pore volume but also significantly improve gas-binding abilities (especially for CO2), thereby enhancing gas uptake and selectivity. Work along this strategy is currently underway in our laboratory.

cln_elements.content:
5-Aminoisophthalic acid (2.70 g, 95%, 15.0 mmol) was dissolved in 40 mL of anhydrous N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone. While under nitrogen flow at 0 °C, oxalyl chloride (0.668 g, 5.26 mmol) was added all at once. After stirring for 30 min at 0 °C and 12 h at room temperature, the reaction mixture was poured into a large excess of water. The precipitated solids were filtered off and washed repeatedly with hot methanol and then dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C to obtain about 0.9 g (yield: ∼41%) of clean H4BDPO as a white powder. Anal. Calcd for C18H12N2O10: C, 51.93; H, 2.91; N, 6.73. Found: C, 51.89; H, 3.14; N, 6.79. Selected IR (KBr, cm–1): 3102, 1713, 1608, 1541, 1457, 1393, 1301, 1227, 1172, 910, 791, 761, 669. 1H NMR (DMSO-d 6, δ ppm): 13.331 (broad peak, COOH), 11.269 (s, 2H, CONH), 8.725 (d, 4H, ArH), 8.272 (s, 2H, ArH).

Synthesis of HNUST-3

H4BDPO (10.4 mg, 0.025 mmol), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (25 mg, 0.1 mmol), DMF (2 mL), ethanol (1.6 mL), H2O (1.6 mL), and concentrated HNO3 (400 μL) were mixed and stirred for a few minutes in air and then the clear solution was transferred into a autoclave Teflon-line stainless vessel (20 mL). The vessel was sealed and heated at 75 °C for 2 days and then cooled to room temperature. Pale-blue block crystals of HNUST-3 were obtained and then washed by DMF to yield about 10.0 mg (yield: ∼70% based on the ligand). The crystals of HNUST-3 are stable for common organic solvents except for water, and it becomes opaque after exposure for several minutes in air. Satisfactory elemental analysis data could not be obtained, despite several attempts. This could be attributed to the fact that the extent of the solvent molecules in the cavity may vary from the exposure time of the sample to air. Selected IR (KBr, cm–1): 1654, 1586, 1374, 1413, 1253, 1174, 1105, 776, 730.

cln_elements.content:
A microporous oxalamide-functionalized NbO-type metal–organic framework, HNUST-3, has been designed and synthesized by self-assembling [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheel SBUs and a novel tetracarboxylate ligand with linking oxalamide groups. HNUST-3 represents the first example of a porous oxalamide-functionalized MOF, which exhibits a high BET surface area of 2412 m2·g–1, large H2 uptake (unsaturated total capacity of 6.1 wt % at 20 bar and 77 K), and excellent CH4 storage (135.8 cm3(STP)cm–3 at 20 bar and 298 K) as well as high CO2 adsorption capacity (20.2 mmol·g–1 at 20 bar and 298 K) with good selectivity for CO2 over CH4 (7.9) and N2 (26.1) at 298 K.

We are interested in the construction of porous functionalized MOF materials from large multidentate carboxylate ligands with linking functionalities (−CONH–, −CC–, etc.) because such an approach may facilitate the generation of expanded frameworks with high surface area and, most importantly, the gas sorption capacity of MOFs may be dramatically enhanced by strong interactions between target gas molecules and the functional groups predesigned in the frameworks. By working with this consideration, very recently we successfully inserted linking acylamide functional groups into several MOFs and realized a balance between high gas-binding ability and large gas-storage capacity. To expand our work in this area, we herein report an oxalamide-functionalized microporous NbO-type MOF, termed HNUST-3 (HNUST denotes Hunan University of Science and Technology), designed from a tetracarboxylate ligand with bridging oxalamide moiety (N,N′-bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)oxalamide = H4BDPO, Scheme ). To the best of our knowledge, HNUST-3 represents the first example of a porous oxalamide-functionalized MOF. HNUST-3 exhibits a high Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 2412 m2·g–1 and a large unsaturated total hydrogen-storage capacity of 6.1 wt % at 77 K and 20 bar. Additionally, this MOF material also demonstrates excellent CH4 storage of 135.8 cm3(STP)cm–3 at 20 bar and 298 K and high CO2 uptake capacity of 20.2 mmol·g–1 at 20 bar and 298 K as well as good selectivity of CO2/N2 (26.1) and CO2/CH4 (7.9).

Single-Crystal X-ray Structure Determination

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction was performed with a Bruker Smart Apex CCD diffractometer with a graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using the ω-scan technique at 298 K. The CCD data were integrated and scaled using the Bruker-SAINT software package. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix leas-squares techniques based on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. The non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and H atoms were placed in calculated positions with isotropic displacement parameters set to 1.2 × U eq of the attached atom. Disordered, independent solvent molecules inside the frameworks were eliminated in the refinement by PLATON/SQUEEZE. Structural information of HNUST-3 was deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC reference number ). Crystallographic data for HNUST-3: C54H24Cu6N6O35.56, fw = 1707.07, monoclinic, P21/c, a = 28.180(2) Å, b = 18.4040(14) Å, c = 32.044(2) Å, α = γ = 90°, β = 112.1740(10)°, V = 15389.7(19) Å3, Z = 4, T = 293(2) K, μ = 0.857 mm–1, 116 696 reflections were collected (28 132 were unique) for 1.30° < θ < 25.35°, R(int) = 0.0691, R 1 = 0.0675, wR 2 = 0.1840 [I > 2σ(I)], R 1 = 0.0921, wR 2 = 0.1963 (all data), GOF = 1.001.

The framework stability of HNUST-3 was studied by both thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements. TGA of the fresh HNUST-3 sample revealed that HNUST-3 loses guest DMF solvent molecules trapped in the cages and coordinated water molecules from 30 to ∼200 °C, and a further significant weight loss is observed up to 300 °C (). To obtain the fully desolvated framework, the fresh HNUST-3 sample was repeatedly soaked in anhydrous acetone for 3 days to exchange the less volatile DMF solvent followed by heating under a dynamic vacuum at 100 °C overnight. A color change from pale-blue to purple-blue occurred, indicating that open Cu(II) sites have been generated similar to those observed for other frameworks. The PXRD patterns of desolvated HNUST-3 are completely identical to those for both as-synthesized and simulated from single-crystal data (Figure ), indicating that the framework is robust and retains its crystallinity after activation.

Permanent Porosity

To evaluate the permanent porosity of HNUST-3, N2 (77 K) and Ar (87 K) gas adsorption studies were performed on the activated sample. As shown in Figure , both isotherms exhibit typical type-I adsorption behavior, as expected for microporous materials. On the basis of the N2 adsorption isotherm, the surface area of activated HNUST-3 calculated from the Langmuir equation is about 2784 m2·g–1, and the corresponding BET surface area is 2412 m2·g–1. This BET value is smaller than that reported for isoreticular analoge NJU-Bai12 (3038 m2·g–1), NOTT-102 (2942 m2·g–1), and NOTT-103 (2929 m2·g–1), but it is significantly larger than that of NOTT-109 (1718 m2·g–1) and PCN-14 (1753 m2·g–1) and is fairly comparable to the values of other highly porous NbO-type MOFs such as SNU-50 (2300 m2·g–1), NOTT-101 (2316 m2·g–1), HNUST-2 (2366 m2·g–1), NOTT-105 (2387 m2·g–1), and PCN-46 (2500 m2·g–1), thus making HNUST-3 among the highest surface area NbO-type MOF series reported to date. The inset to Figure shows the differential pore volume distributions as functions of pore width calculated by nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) from N2 isotherm data, which suggests that HNUST-3 has a narrow pore-size distributions around 1.0–1.2 nm, corresponding with the crystal model. The total pore volume of HNUST-3 calculated from the maximum amount of N2 adsorbed at 77 K reaches up to 0.99 cm3·g–1, consistent with the total framework pore volume (1.07 cm3·g–1) derived from the X-ray crystal structure of HNUST-3.

Gas Storage Properties

Because of its high power density of 33.3 kW h kg–1 (higher than methane at 13.9 kW h kg–1 and gasoline at 12.4 kW h kg–1), abundance, and nonpolluting nature, hydrogen is considered to be an ideal energy source candidate in the future. However, the lack of an effective storage method hinders the realization of the hydrogen economy era. During the past 2 decades, porous MOFs have been highlighted as promising candidates for use as a hydrogen storage material by virtue of their high porosity, tunable pore size, and large internal surface area. The high porosity and stable framework with open copper(II) sites suggest HNUST-3 may have an excellent H2 storage property. Indeed, HNUST-3 exhibits a high total H2-uptake capacity of 2.2 wt % [wt % = 100(mass of adsorbed gas)/(mass of MOF)] at 77 K and 1 bar (), which is larger than the corresponding value of PCN-46 (1.9 wt %) and is among the highest H2 uptakes at low pressure. High-pressure gravimetric H2 adsorption data were also recorded over the pressure range 0–20 bar at 77 K (Figure ), and HNUST-3 gives a maximum excess H2 uptake of 5.4 wt % (37.0 g·L–1) at 20 bar with no hysteresis. Taking into consideration the gaseous hydrogen compressed within the framework void, the total H2 uptake capacity of HNUST-3 can reach as high as 6.1 wt % (41.8 g·L–1) at 20 bar and 77 K, which is moderate compared with the highest capacity MOF materials. On the basis of the adsorption isotherms measured at 77 and 87 K, the zero-coverage H2 adsorption enthalpy of HNUST-3 is calculated to be 6.38 kJ·mol–1 with the virial method, which is quite large compared to other Cu(II)-based metal polyhedral frameworks with average adsorption enthalpies of 5.6–6.2 kJ·mol–1.

Carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) has been proposed as a feasible method for controlling atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration. MOF-based porous materials exhibit great potential in CCS because they can store greater amounts of CO2 than other classes of porous materials and their chemically adjustable organic and inorganic moieties can be carefully predesigned to be suitable for molecular recognition of CO2. Our recent work clearly demonstrates that insertion of acylamide groups into porous MOFs can significantly increase the CO2-uptake capacity and selectivity of the materials because of the enhanced CO2-binding affinity. The BDPO ligand features similar linking oxalamide groups, and this prompted us to investigate the CO2-uptake performance of HNUST-3. Interestingly, HNUST-3 can adsorb substantial amounts of CO2 with uptake capacities of 33.15 wt % at 273 K and 16.6 wt % at 298 K under 1 atm of pressure (). These values are quite larger than that of the best performing ZIF material (ZIF-20, 13.7 wt % at 273 K and 1 atm), PCN-46 (ca. 13.2 wt % at 298 K and 1 atm), SUN-50 (21 wt % at 273 K and 1 atm), and most of other highly porous MOFs under the same conditions. Notably, as shown in Figure , the CO2 uptake amounts of HNUST-3 at 273 and 298 K are not saturated at 20 bar, with the values of 98.9 and 89.0 wt % (about 22.47 and 20.23 mmol·g–1), respectively. This CO2-uptake capacity is greater than those of some typical high-surface-area MOFs reported, such as MOF-210 (16.0 mmol·g–1), MOF-200 (14.8 mmol·g–1), and MOF-5 (19.0 mmol·g–1) at 20 bar and 298 K. In addition, on the basis of the total capacity, a container filled with HNUST-3 can store about 16 times the amount of CO2 in an empty container at 20 bar and 298 K, further indicating that HNUST-3 is a good and efficient CO2 adsorbent.

A microporous oxalamide-functionalized NbO-type metal-organic framework, HNUST-3, has been designed and synthesized by self-assembling [Cu2(COO)4] paddlewheel SBUs and a novel tetracarboxylate ligand with linking oxalamide groups. HNUST-3 represents the first example of a porous oxalamide-functionalized MOF, which exhibits a high BET surface area of 2412 m2⋅g-1, large H2 uptake (unsaturated total capacity of 6.1 wt % at 20 bar and 77 K), and excellent CH4 storage (135.8 cm3(STP)cm-3 at 20 bar and 298 K) as well as high CO2 adsorption capacity (20.2 mmol⋅g-1 at 20 bar and 298 K) with good selectivity for CO2 over CH4 (7.9) and N2 (26.1) at 298 K.

We are interested in the construction of porous functionalized MOF materials from large multidentate carboxylate ligands with linking functionalities (-CONH-, -CC-, etc.) because such an approach may facilitate the generation of expanded frameworks with high surface area and, most importantly, the gas sorption capacity of MOFs may be dramatically enhanced by strong interactions between target gas molecules and the functional groups predesigned in the frameworks. By working with this consideration, very recently we successfully inserted linking acylamide functional groups into several MOFs and realized a balance between high gas-binding ability and large gas-storage capacity. To expand our work in this area, we herein report an oxalamide-functionalized microporous NbO-type MOF, termed HNUST-3 (HNUST denotes Hunan University of Science and Technology), designed from a tetracarboxylate ligand with bridging oxalamide moiety (N,N'-bis(3,5-dicarboxyphenyl)oxalamide = H4BDPO, Scheme ). To the best of our knowledge, HNUST-3 represents the first example of a porous oxalamide-functionalized MOF. HNUST-3 exhibits a high Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 2412 m2⋅g-1 and a large unsaturated total hydrogen-storage capacity of 6.1 wt % at 77 K and 20 bar. Additionally, this MOF material also demonstrates excellent CH4 storage of 135.8 cm3(STP)cm-3 at 20 bar and 298 K and high CO2 uptake capacity of 20.2 mmol⋅g-1 at 20 bar and 298 K as well as good selectivity of CO2/N2 (26.1) and CO2/CH4 (7.9).

Disordered, independent solvent molecules inside the frameworks were eliminated in the refinement by PLATON/SQUEEZE. Structural information of HNUST-3 was deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC reference number ). cln_elements.content: Methane gas is another alternative on-board fuel that has attracted much interest. Compared with H2 storage, MOFs offer much more promise for use in CH4 storage because higher CH4 adsorption performance can be achieved. Up until now, several MOF compounds have been reported to exhibit exceptional CH4 uptake that surpasses the DOE standard (180 cm3·cm–3) at room temperature and 35 bar. Notably, a MOF methane fuel tank has already been implemented in test vehicles. To investigate the CH4 gas-storage capacity of HNUST-3, a gravimetric CH4 adsorption isotherm was recorded up to 20 bar at both 273 and 298 K. As shown in Figure , the CH4 isotherm also shows typical type-I behavior with good reversibility and fast kinetics. Most importantly, HNUST-3 possesses a completely reversible high CH4 adsorption at near ambient temperature. A large unsaturation excess CH4 uptake of 18.75 and 14.14 wt % (∼ 11.7 and 8.8 mmol·g–1) is observed at 273 and 298 K under 20 bar, respectively, corresponding to volumetric (v/v) uptakes of 180.1 and 135.8 cm3(STP)cm–3. This CH4 uptake capacity is lower than the DOE standard, but it is comparable to other MOF materials under higher pressures at 298 K (Mg-MOF-74, 149 cm3(STP)cm–3 at 35 bar; IRMOF-1, 135 cm3(STP)cm–3 at 35 bar; and MIL-101c, 100 cm3(STP)cm–3 at 35 bar).
